Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14 (landlord obligations concerning repair and maintenance of leased premises and common areas).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 15B.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 15B (statutory protections against retaliatory action by landlords).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (Summary process; general venue and related landlord-tenant procedural provisions).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Unfair and Deceptive Practices Act) (statutory remedy for unfair or deceptive acts; landlord misconduct sometimes alleged under c.93A).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, ch. 111 \u00a7.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, ch. 111 § 127A et seq.
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, ch. 111 \u00a7.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, ch. 111 § 127A et seq. (public health and sanitary code provisions applicable to habitability and safety).

Mass. R. Civ. P. 8, 12, 56.proposition: Mass. R. Civ. P. 8, 12, 56 (pleading, defenses, summary judgment procedures).

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (landlord duty to maintain premises and tenant remedies; foundational modern precedent on implied warranty of habitability and tenant protections).

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (failure to secure common areas and landlord liability).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about recognizing and defining the implied warranty of habitability and related remedies. Common areas are mentioned only in a footnote specifying that the warranty extends to facilities in common areas that affect health or safety (e.g., stairways, porches), but the case does not address landlord liability for failure to secure common areas (such as security from crime, locks, or similar issues). Thus, citing Hilder for the specific proposition of failure to secure common areas and landlord liability overstates what the case holds.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit. … The warranty also covers those facilities located in the common areas of an apartment building or duplex that may affect the health or safety of a tenant, such as common stairways, or porches.”

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (discussing covenant of habitability and tenant protections; often cited in landlord-tenant jurisprudence).
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes and adopts a common law implied warranty (covenant) of habitability in residential leases and allows tenants to assert breach of that warranty as a defense in unlawful detainer actions. It also discusses the scope of the landlord’s obligations, tenant remedies, and how the habitability breach affects rent and possession, making it a foundational landlord–tenant case frequently cited for tenant protections in California.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. This implied warranty of habitability does not require that a landlord ensure that leased premises are in perfect, aesthetically pleasing condition, but it does mean that ‘bare living requirements’ must be maintained.”
